client_profile: Couple seeking to buy an apartment in Brussels. Budget is 790,000-1,260,000 EUR. Priorities include restaurants, cafes, and residential quiet.
red_flags: Potential budget stretch in prime areas
contradictions: Desire for quiet versus proximity to lively cafes
Focus on value versus high-end properties
Preference for central access versus quieter outskirts

top_districts.name: Ixelles
why: Châtelain offers vibrant cafes and brunch spots, attracting expats and young professionals.
Flagey features shops and a lively public square, enhancing community interaction.
watch_out: Popular streets experience noise on weekends, and parking is often tight.

top_districts.name: Etterbeek
why: Jourdan district has diverse restaurants and cafes, popular with young professionals.
Cinquantenaire park provides green space and family-friendly activities within reach.
watch_out: Rents near the EU quarter can be higher, potentially stretching the budget.

top_districts.name: Saint-Gilles
why: Parvis de Saint-Gilles offers trendy brunch spots and a vibrant art scene.
Barriere features eclectic shops integrated into a lively neighborhood atmosphere.
watch_out: Some streets can be noisy late; choose quieter side streets to relax.

questions_for_agent_landlord: What is the total cost including taxes and fees?
Are there any building charges or planned works?
What is the condition of the property assessed?
Can you provide a timeline for the purchase process?
Are there any legal compliance issues I should be aware of?
next_steps: Review listings on suggested real estate sites.
Schedule visits to top districts of interest.
Consult with real estate agents for insights.
Prepare financial documents for potential purchases.
clarifying_questions: What is the preferred move-in date?
Are there specific amenities or features required?
Is there flexibility on the budget range?
